newsitem.title: UK: UK accountants give victorious Labour wish list.
newsitem.headline: UK accountants give victorious Labour wish list.

text.p: Britain's Association of Chartered Certified Accountants (ACCA) on Friday called on the victorious Labour party to address 10 key issues aimed at helping small businesses.

"If appropriate measures are taken, the small business sector will expand, make an even more significant contribution to the economy that it is doing already," the association's president Peter Langard said in a statement.
This focus on small business would also improve employment prospects, Langard said.
At the top of its list, ACCA urged the new Labour government, which on Thursday won a dramatic landslide victory against the ruling Conservative party, to simplify tax legislation.
"The complexity of tax legislation causes problems even for large companies and is particularly onerous for smaller businesses," it said.
ACCA called for a lower rate of corporation tax on the first 100,000 pounds of retained profits to encourage re-investment and the removal of tax barriers for small firms wishing to "disincorporate".
For small firms in temporary financial difficulties, ACCA proposed a central co-ordinating agency to reschedule debt for tax, value-added-tax (VAT) and national insurance purposes.

On a more general level, ACCA asked Labour to review the question of external scrutiny of the accounts of charitable companies and a permanent exclusion from audit exemption regulations for small companies.

It welcomed a Labour commitment to undertake a review of the law on joint and several liability. And it urged the active promotion of environmental reporting and "an urgent review into the feasibility of mandatory environmental reporting for all environmentally sensitive companies".

Finally ACCA said it agreed with Labour proposals to simplify capital gains tax. "The tax is too complex and the government should seek to tax short term gains, with a taper relief for longer term gains," it added.
